newsitem.title: GERMANY: Ireland's Quinn sees European unemployment falling.
newsitem.headline: Ireland's Quinn sees European unemployment falling.

text.p: Irish Finance Minister Ruairi Quinn said on Friday that Europe's worryingly high levels of unemployment should begin to fall as economic growth picks up.

Quinn, also President of the Ecofin council of the European Union, told a banking congress in Frankfurt: "The rise in European unemployment should be reversed with a downward trend being established as growth accelerates."
Unemployment in the EU has risen from under 8.5 percent in 1990 to a projected 11 percent this year.

High unemployment has driven up social spending and reduced tax income, making it harder for European nations to reduce budget deficits, necessary for compliance with the Maastricht criteria required for currency union.
But Quinn said he was optimistic that economic growth would pick up.
"The current indications are that the impact of monetary easing earlier this year will help deliver a return to higher growth rates," Quinn said.

Quinn, who said unemployment is a top priority of the Irish presidency of the Ecofin council, added that unemployment requires consistent pro-employment measures on the part of the EU to reduce what he called an unacceptably high, "unnatural" level of unemployment.
